div1.head: Jim to Mademoiselle Marcelle Guerin March 26 1916
div1.p: Your welcome letter was received this noon. I am terribly sorry to hear your ankle has gone back on you. You ought to rest until its quite well. Maybe those refreshing walks set it back.

I have but little time left on the Nieuport but when finished I do not know what I shall do. I hope to be called to the front but reports aren’t very encouraging. The bunch that
left here not so long ago were supposed to go directly to the front. They write that they are tied up at Plaissey — Belleville. They are considered ready for the front and will only be held two months, so they write, and go on to say that if they had not been perfectioned at Pau but sent to P.B for same they would have been held six months. Cheerful prospect isn’t it? I am told that I will be ready inside of two weeks. I wrote to Watt [or Walt] asking him to have me sent to Toul. He’s leaving for Australian flying corps. D____! My friend Le Bourbis has been
wounded. The Chef pilote that was here when I arrived and who told us good by a couple of weeks ago was shot in the leg above the lines and has lost his left limb. Poor chap he was a fine fellow. There are peculiar accidents here. The other day a fellow fainted at 2,000 meters and his machine fell that distance, and on its back. They say the pilot has almost recovered. The same day one came down from only 100 meters and was killed on the spot.

Since starting this letter I have been over to
the Boche camp just across the road. Sundays they clean up and then there is a review. They passed the French officer with the goose step. Their arms are rigid at their side, the head faces the officer and the straight legs work like levers. The feet pounding on the road make the very ground tremble. At first I was impressed, then amused, and then I was shocked that a system could turn men into such a machine depriving them of all human character; finally I pitied the poor brutes because they had to become machines.

I am sitting in a hanger, using as a support
for the letter a sugar box. Its the only time I have[.]
The reason I sent letters to the S.S. was because I fear your father and mother do not want you to receive letters from me. By the way did you get the photos I sent you? x x x Later.

Nearly polished myself off a few minutes ago. We started to fly and I went
out. Coming back I started a spiral at 1,000 meters and thinking about my lean I didn’t pay much attention to my angle of descent. First thing I knew I’d flopped from the side to a vertical dive. I figured my controls were just reversed then as I had been told. The rudder would point me up and down and the marche a falai [sp?] to right or left. I worked out of it but the fellows told me they thought the fusilage [sic] would snap when I straightened and
had figured me out as dead. The Nieuforts are very strong tho [sic] and one can do all sorts of things with them.

Tell me one thing. If I get any time off when I pass thru [sic] Paris may I see you? I will go to hospital or any place you say. There was a chance to day to go to Paris Guard. No one would take the job. Lots were drawn and three are billed for that fool work.

My friend Haviland is
doing remarkably well. He’ll be breveted in a week and I hope sent to Nieuport with me. There are no more brevet permissions. Wish I hadn’t been given one.
